abstract.text: Install and run GUI Linux in a virtual machine using the Virtualization framework.

metadata.title: Running GUI Linux in a virtual machine on a Mac

inlineContent.text: This sample code project demonstrates how to install and run GUI Linux virtual machines (VMs) on a Mac.
The Xcode project includes a single target,
, which is a macOS app that installs a Linux distribution from an ISO image into a VM, and subsequently runs the installed Linux VM.
Before you run the sample program, you need to download an ISO installation image from a Linux distribution website. Some common Linux distributions include:

The Virtualization framework can run Linux VMs on a Mac with Apple silicon, and on an Intel-based Mac. The Linux ISO image you download must support the CPU architecture of your Mac. For a Mac with Apple silicon, download a Linux ISO image for ARM, which is usually indicated by
or
in the image filename. For an Intel-based Mac, download a Linux ISO image for Intel-compatible CPUs, which is usually indicated by
or
in the image filename.

If you need to run Intel Linux binaries in ARM Linux on a Mac with Apple silicon, the Virtualization framework supports this capability using the Rosetta translation environment. For more information, see

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Running Intel Binaries in Linux VMs with Rosetta

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Running Intel Binaries in Linux VMs with Rosetta

inlineContent.text: The default deployment target is macOS14, if you need to build for a different version of macOS you’ll need to change the deployment target as appropriate.
Launch Xcode and open
Navigate to the Signing & Capabilities panel and select your team ID.

Build and run GUILinuxVirtualMachineSampleApp. The sample app starts the VM and configures a graphical view that you interact with. The Linux VM continues running until you shut it down from the guest OS, or when you quit the app.

When you run the app for the first time, it displays a file picker so you can choose the Linux installation ISO image to use for installing your Linux VM. Navigate to the ISO image that you downloaded, select the file, and click Open. The VM boots into the OS installer, and the installer’s user interface appears in the app’s window. Follow the installation instructions. When the installation finishes, the Linux VM is ready to use.
As part of the installation process, the Virtualization framework creates a

package in your home directory. The sample app only supports running one VM at a time, however, the Virtualization framework supports running multiple VMs simultaneously. Running multiple VMs requires an app to manage the execution and artifacts of each individual VM.
The contents of the bundle represent the state of the Linux guest, and contain the following:
— The main disk image of the installed Linux OS.
— The data representation of the
object.
— The EFI variable store.
Subsequent launches of GUILinuxVirtualMachineSampleApp run the installed Linux VM. To reinstall the VM, delete the
package and run the app again.

content.text: Enable copy-and-paste support between the host and the guest

inlineContent.text: In macOS 13 and later, the Virtualization framework supports copy-and-paste of text and images between the Mac host and Linux guests through the SPICE agent clipboard-sharing capability. The example below shows the steps for configuring
and
to enable this capability:
To use the copy-and-paste capability in Linux, the user needs to install the
package, which is available through most Linux package managers. Developers need to communicate this requirement to users of their apps.
After building the configuration data for the VM, the sample app uses the
object to start the execution of the Linux guest operating system.
Before calling the VM’s
method, the sample app configures a delegate object to receive messages about the state of the virtual machine. When the Linux operating system shuts down, the VM calls the delegate’s
method. In response, the delegate method prints a message and exits the sample.

code: // Configure the app to automatically respond changes in the display size.
fatalError("Virtual machine failed to start with error: \(error)")

inlineContent.text: The app sets the display to automatically resize when the window size changes.

abstract.text: Create virtual machines and run macOS and Linux-based operating systems.
The boot loader configuration the system uses to boot guest-operating systems that expect an Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) ROM.
An attachment point that enables the Spice clipboard sharing capability.
A console device that enables communication between the host and the guest using console ports through a Virtio interface.
An object that manages the overall state and configuration of your VM.
Starts the VM and notifies the specified completion handler if startup is successful.
The environment attributes and list of devices to use during the configuration of macOS or Linux VMs.
Tells the delegate that the guest operating system stopped the VM.
Improve Rosetta performance by adding support for the total store ordering (TSO) memory model to your Linux kernel.
Design and run custom Linux guests on Apple silicon or Intel-based Mac Computers.
